questions.qText: Calculate \( E_{OP} \) for half cell: \( \text{Ag} \, | \, \text{AgNO}_3 \, (0.1 \, \text{M}) \). Given \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Ag}^+/\text{Ag}} = 1.1 \, \text{V} \).

Calculate the emf of the cell at 25°C: \( \text{Fe} \, | \, \text{Fe}^{2+} \, (0.3 \, \text{M}) \, || \, \text{Sn}^{2+} \, (0.1 \, \text{M}) \, | \, \text{Sn} \). Given \( E^{\circ}_{\text{OP,H}} = 0 \, \text{V} \), \( E^{\circ}_{\text{OP,Fe}} = 0.44 \, \text{V} \), and \( E^{\circ}_{\text{OP,Sn}} = 0.14 \, \text{V} \).

Calculate the emf of the cell at 25°C: \( \text{Pt} \, | \, \text{H}_2 \, (2 \, \text{atm}) \, | \, \text{HCl} \, | \, \text{H}_2 \, (10 \, \text{atm}) \, | \, \text{Pt} \). Given \( E^{\circ}_{\text{OP,H}} = 0 \, \text{V} \).
The standard electrode potential of Cu/Cu\(^{2+}\) is -0.34 volt. At what concentration of Cu\(^{2+}\) ions, will this electrode potential be zero?

For the cell \( \text{Zn} \, | \, \text{Zn}^{2+} \, (1 \, \text{M}) \, || \, \text{Cu}^{2+} \, (1 \, \text{M}) \, | \, \text{Cu} \), given that \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Cu}^{2+}/\text{Cu}} = 0.35 \, \text{V} \) and \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Zn}^{2+}/\text{Zn}} = -0.763 \, \text{V} \), calculate the emf of the cell initially.

For the cell \( \text{Zn} \, | \, \text{Zn}^{2+} \, (1 \, \text{M}) \, || \, \text{Cu}^{2+} \, (1 \, \text{M}) \, | \, \text{Cu} \), if the cell is allowed to operate spontaneously and [Cu\(^{2+}\)] has fallen to 0.500 M, what will be the emf of the cell?

For the cell \( \text{Zn} \, | \, \text{Zn}^{2+} \, (1 \, \text{M}) \, || \, \text{Cu}^{2+} \, (1 \, \text{M}) \, | \, \text{Cu} \), what will be the [Zn\(^{2+}\)] when \( E_{\text{cell}} = 1.10 \, \text{V} \)?

The emf of a cell corresponding to the reaction \( \text{Zn(s)} + 2\text{H}^+(aq.) \longrightarrow \text{Zn}^{2+} (0.1 \, \text{M}) + \text{H}_2(g) (1 \, \text{atm}) \) is 0.28 V at 25°C and \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Zn}/\text{Zn}^{2+}} = 0.76 \, \text{V} \). Calculate the pH of the solution at H electrode.

From the standard emf: \( 2\text{Ag} + \text{Pt}^{2+} \longrightarrow 2\text{Ag}^+ + \text{Pt}; \quad E^\circ = 0.4 \, \text{V} \) and \( 2\text{Ag} + \text{F}_2 \longrightarrow 2\text{Ag}^+ + 2\text{F}^-; \quad E^\circ = 2.07 \, \text{V} \), if standard potential for the reaction Pt → Pt\(^{2+}\) + 2e is assigned as zero, determine the standard potential for Ag → Ag\(^+\) + e.

From the standard emf: \( 2\text{Ag} + \text{Pt}^{2+} \longrightarrow 2\text{Ag}^+ + \text{Pt}; \quad E^\circ = 0.4 \, \text{V} \) and \( 2\text{Ag} + \text{F}_2 \longrightarrow 2\text{Ag}^+ + 2\text{F}^-; \quad E^\circ = 2.07 \, \text{V} \), if standard potential for the reaction Pt → Pt\(^{2+}\) + 2e is assigned as zero, determine the standard potential for F\(^-\) → \( \frac{1}{2} \) F\(_2\) + e.

Calculate the equilibrium constant at 25°C for the reaction: \( \text{Hg}_2(\text{NO}_3)_2 + 2\text{Fe}(\text{NO}_3)_2 \rightleftharpoons 2\text{Hg} + 2\text{Fe}(\text{NO}_3)_3 \). Given \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Hg}_2^{2+}/\text{Hg}} = 0.79 \, \text{V} \) and \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Fe}^{3+}/\text{Fe}^{2+}} = 0.77 \, \text{V} \).

Calculate the equilibrium constant for the reaction: \( \text{Cu} + \text{Cu}^{2+} \rightleftharpoons 2\text{Cu}^+ \). Given \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Cu}^{2+}/\text{Cu}} = 0.34 \, \text{V} \) and \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Cu}^{+}/\text{Cu}} = 0.15 \, \text{V} \).

Calculate the emf of the cell at 25°C: \( \text{PbSO}_4 \, | \, \text{saturated solution} \, || \, \text{PbI}_2 \, | \, \text{saturated solution} \). \( K_{sp} \) of \( \text{PbSO}_4 = 1.6 \times 10^{-8} \) and \( K_{sp} \) of \( \text{PbI}_2 = 8 \times 10^{-9} \).

How much \( \text{Cu}^{2+} \) ions are present at equilibrium when finely divided Ni is mixed with 0.05 M solution of \( \text{CuSO}_4 \)? Given \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Cu}/\text{Cu}^{2+}} = -0.337 \, \text{V} \) and \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Ni}/\text{Ni}^{2+}} = 0.25 \, \text{V} \).

The \( E^\circ \) for \( \text{Zn}^{2+}/\text{Zn} \) and \( E^\circ \) for \( \text{Cu}^{2+}/\text{Cu} \) are -0.76 and 0.34 V respectively at 25°C. When excess of Zn is added to a solution of \( \text{CuSO}_4 \), the zinc displaces Cu till equilibrium is reached. What is the ratio of concentration of \( \text{Zn}^{2+} \) and \( \text{Cu}^{2+} \) ion at equilibrium?

The reaction \( \text{H}_2 + \text{Cl}_2 + 2\text{H}_2\text{O} \rightleftharpoons 2\text{H}_3\text{O}^+ + 2\text{Cl}^- \) has an equilibrium constant \( K = 10^{46} \) at 25°C. Calculate \( E^\circ \) at 25°C for the cell \( \text{Pt} \, | \, \text{H}_2 \, | \, \text{HCl}(aq.) \, | \, \text{Cl}_2 \, | \, \text{Pt} \).

The cell \( \text{Pt} \, | \, \text{H}_2 \, (1 \, \text{atm}) \, | \, \text{H}^+ \, (pH = X) \, || \, \text{Normal calomel electrode} \) has emf of 0.67 V at 25°C. Calculate pH of solution. The oxidation potential of calomel electrode on H scale is -0.28 V.

A cell is set up where the overall reaction is \( \text{H}_2(g) + \text{Sn}^{4+} \rightarrow 2\text{H}^+ + \text{Sn}^{2+} \). The hydrogen electrode is under standard condition and \( E_{cell} \) is found to be +0.20 V. What is the ratio of \( \text{Sn}^{2+} \) to \( \text{Sn}^{4+} \) around the other electrode? Given \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Sn}^{4+}/\text{Sn}^{2+}} = 0.15 \, \text{V} \).

A hydrogen electrode having \( P_{H_2} = 1.00 \) atm is combined with a standard calomel electrode, whose half-reaction is: \( \text{Hg}_2\text{Cl}_2(s) + 2e \longrightarrow 2\text{Hg}(l) + 2\text{Cl}^-; \quad E^\circ = 0.242 \, \text{V} \). If the cell potential is 0.800 V, what is the pH of the solution around the hydrogen electrode?
For the cell in question 58, what will the cell potential be if the hydrogen electrode is immersed in a neutral solution?

A complete cell is made by combining a standard copper electrode with another copper electrode in which \( [\text{Cu}^{2+}] = 10^{-2} \, \text{M} \). When this cell functions as a voltaic cell, what will be the overall cell potential?

At 25°C, the free energy of formation of \( \text{H}_2\text{O}(l) \) is -56700 cal mol^{-1} while that of its ionisation to (\( \text{H}^+ + \text{OH}^- \)) is 19050 cal mol^{-1}. What is the reversible emf of the cell \( \text{H}_2(g) (1 \, \text{atm}) \, || \, \text{H}^+ \, || \, \text{OH}^- \, || \, \text{O}_2(g) \, (1 \, \text{atm}) \)?
What is emf of a cell containing two H electrodes, the negative one in contact with \( 10^{-6} \, \text{M} \, \text{OH}^- \) and the positive one in contact with 0.05 M \( \text{H}^+ \)?

Calculate \( K_C \) for \( \text{Hg}^{2+} + \text{Hg} \rightleftharpoons \text{Hg}_2^{2+} \). Given that, \( E^\circ_{2\text{Hg}/\text{Hg}_2^{2+}} = -0.788 \, \text{V} \) and \( E^\circ_{\text{Hg}_2^{2+}/2\text{Hg}^{2+}} = -0.920 \, \text{V} \).

A Galvanic cell is constructed with \( \text{Ag}^+ / \text{Ag} \) and \( \text{Fe}^{3+} / \text{Fe}^{2+} \) electrodes. Find the concentration of \( \text{Ag}^+ \) at which the emf of the cell is zero at equimolar concentration of \( \text{Fe}^{2+} \) and \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \). Given \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Ag}^+ / \text{Ag}} = 0.80 \, \text{V} \) and \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Fe}^{3+} / \text{Fe}^{2+}} = 0.77 \, \text{V} \).

The emf of cell \( \text{Zn} \, | \, \text{Zn}^{2+} \, (0.01 \, \text{M}) \, || \, \text{Fe}^{3+} \, (0.001 \, \text{M}) \, | \, \text{Fe}^{2+} \) is 1.71 volt at 25°C. Calculate equilibrium constant of the cell reaction \( \text{Zn} + 2\text{Fe}^{3+} \rightleftharpoons \text{Zn}^{2+} + 2\text{Fe}^{2+} \) at 25°C.

The potential for the reaction: \( \text{O}_2 (g) + 4\text{H}^+ + 4e \longrightarrow 2\text{H}_2\text{O} \) is 1.23 V in 0.1 N strong acid solution. Calculate the potential of this couple in aqueous solution of pH = 10.

The potential for the reaction: \( \text{O}_2 (g) + 4\text{H}^+ + 4e \longrightarrow 2\text{H}_2\text{O} \) is 1.23 V in 0.1 N strong acid solution. Calculate the potential of this couple in aqueous solution of pH = 14.

For AgI, the solubility product \( K_{sp} = 1 \times 10^{-16} \). What will be the electrode potential of \( \text{Ag}^+ / \text{Ag} \) electrode at 25°C in a saturated solution of AgI in water? \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Ag}^+ / \text{Ag}} = 0.80 \, \text{V} \)

A silver wire dipped in 0.1M HCl solution saturated with AgCl develops a potential of -0.250 V. Calculate \( K_{sp} \) of AgCl in pure water if \( E^{\circ}_{\text{Ag}^+ / \text{Ag}} = -0.799 \, \text{V} \)

\( K_{sp} \) of AgCl is \( 1.8 \times 10^{-10} \). Calculate oxidation electrode potential for Ag-AgCl electrode having \( [\text{Cl}^-] = 1 \, \text{M} \). Given \( E^{\circ}_{\text{OP, Ag}^+ / \text{Ag}} = -0.799 \, \text{V} \)
\( K_{sp} \) of Cu(OH)\(_2\) is \( 1.0 \times 10^{-19} \). Calculate the reduction potential at pH = 14 for the couple Cu\(^{2+}\)/Cu. Given \( E^\circ_{RP} \) of Cu\(^{2+}\)/Cu = 0.34 V.

What is the minimum conc. of Ag\(^+\) that would remain unreduced by a standard Fe\(^{3+}\)/Fe\(^{2+}\) electrode at equilibrium? \( E^\circ_{\text{Fe}^{3+}/\text{Fe}^{2+}} = 0.771 \, \text{V} \) and \( E^\circ_{\text{Ag}^+/ \text{Ag}} = 0.799 \, \text{V} \)
The free energy change accompanying a given process is -85.77 kJ mol^{-1} at 25°C and -83.68 kJ mol^{-1} at 35°C. Calculate the heat of reaction of process at 30°C.

The standard free energy change for the reaction, \( \text{H}_2(g) + 2\text{AgCl}(s) \longrightarrow 2\text{Ag}(s) + 2\text{H}^+(aq.) + 2\text{Cl}^-(aq.) \) is -10.26 kcal mol^{-1} at 25°C. A cell using above reaction is operated at 25°C under \( P_{H_2} = 1 \, \text{atm} \), [H\(^+\)] and [Cl\(^-\)] = 0.1 M. Calculate emf of cell.

For the reaction Fe\(^{3+}\) + 3e \( \rightleftharpoons \) Fe, \( E^\circ \) is -0.036 V and the standard electrode potential for Fe\(^{3+}\) + e \( \rightleftharpoons \) Fe\(^{2+}\) is 0.771 V. Calculate the \( E^\circ \) for Fe\(^{2+}\) + 2e \( \rightleftharpoons \) Fe.

Evaluate \( E^\circ \) for Sn\(^{4+}\) + 2e \( \rightarrow \) Sn\(^{2+} \). Given that \( E^\circ_{\text{Sn}/\text{Sn}^{2+}} = +0.14 \, \text{V} \) and \( E^\circ_{\text{Sn}/\text{Sn}^{4+}} = 0.15 \, \text{V} \).

From the following informations, calculate the overall stability constant \( K_{sp} \) of Ag(S\(_2\)O\(_3\))\(_2^{3-}\) at 25°C. \( \text{Ag}^+ + e \longrightarrow \text{Ag}; \quad E^\circ = 0.799 \, \text{V} \) and \( \text{Ag}(\text{S}_2\text{O}_3)_2^{3-} + e \longrightarrow \text{Ag} + 2\text{S}_2\text{O}_3^{2-}; \quad E^\circ = 0.017 \, \text{V} \)

The emf of a cell \( \text{Pt} \, | \, \text{H}_2 \, | \, \text{HCl} \, (0.1 \, \text{M}) \, | \, \text{AgCl}(s) \, | \, \text{Ag} \) is 0.03525 V at 27°C and 0.03705 V at 17°C. Calculate heat of reaction for \( \frac{1}{2} \text{H}_2 + \text{Ag}^+ \rightarrow \text{H}^+ + \text{Ag} \) at 27°C.

Neglecting the liquid junction potential, calculate the emf of following cell at 25°C: \( \text{H}_2 \, (1 \, \text{atm}) \, | \, 0.5 \, \text{M} \, \text{HCOOH} \, || \, 1 \, \text{M} \, \text{CH}_3\text{COOH} \, | \, \text{H}_2 \, (1 \, \text{atm}) \). \( K_a \) for HCOOH and CH\(_3\)COOH are \( 1.77 \times 10^{-4} \) and \( 1.8 \times 10^{-5} \) respectively.

The emf of the cell \( \text{Cd} \, | \, \text{CdCl}_2 \, (1 \, \text{M}) \, | \, \text{AgCl}(s) \, | \, \text{Ag} \) is 0.675 volt at 25°C. The temperature coefficient of the cell is \( -6.5 \times 10^{-4} \) volt deg.^{-1}. Calculate heat of reaction.
The \( \Delta H \) for the reaction, at 0°C, Zn + 2AgCl = ZnCl\(_2\) + 2Ag is -52.05 kcal. If the emf of the cell is 1.015 volt, what is temperature coefficient of the cell at 0°C?
For the cell Ag | AgCl | KCl(aq.) | Hg\(_2\)Cl\(_2\) | Hg, the emf is 0.0455 V at 298 K and the temperature coefficient is \( 3.38 \times 10^{-4} \) VK^{-1}. What is the free energy change?
For the cell Ag | AgCl | KCl(aq.) | Hg\(_2\)Cl\(_2\) | Hg, the emf is 0.0455 V at 298 K and the temperature coefficient is \( 3.38 \times 10^{-4} \) VK^{-1}. What is the enthalpy change?
For the cell Ag | AgCl | KCl(aq.) | Hg\(_2\)Cl\(_2\) | Hg, the emf is 0.0455 V at 298 K and the temperature coefficient is \( 3.38 \times 10^{-4} \) VK^{-1}. What is the entropy change?
Write the cell reaction and calculate the emf of cell for Cl\(_2\) (1 atm) | NaCl(aq.) | Cl\(_2\) (0.1 atm). Will the cell reaction be spontaneous?
The emf of a galvanic cell composed of two H electrodes is 272 millivolt. What is the pH of the solution in which the anode is immersed if the cathode is in the solution of pH = 3?
Calculate the potential of a cell in which H electrodes are immersed in a solution with a pH of 3.5 and in a solution with a pH of 10.7.
The reversible reduction potential of water is -0.414 V under 1 atm H\(_2\) pressure. If the reduction is \( 2\text{H}^+ + 2e \rightarrow \text{H}_2 \), calculate [H\(^+\)] in pure water.
A cell contains one litre of buffer mixture of CH\(_3\)COOH and CH\(_3\)COONa each 1 M in two compartments using platinum electrodes. p\(K_a\) for CH\(_3\)COOH = 4.74. Calculate the emf of the cell.
For the cell in question 85, after passage of 1.25 A current for 241.25 minute, calculate the emf of the cell.

Calculate the emf of the cell at 18°C for: \( \text{Pt} \, | \, \text{H}_2 \, (1 \, \text{atm}) \, | \, N/10 \, \text{HCl} \, || \, N \, \text{KOH} \, | \, \text{H}_2 \, (1 \, \text{atm}) \). HCl is 90% dissociated and KOH is 75% ionised.

The emf of the cell \( \text{Pt} \, | \, \text{H}_2 \, (1 \, \text{atm}) \, | \, \text{HOCN} \, (1.3 \times 10^{-3} \, M) \, || \, \text{Ag}^+ \, (0.8 \, M) \, | \, \text{Ag}(s) \) is 0.982 V. Calculate the \( K_a \) for HOCN. \( \text{Ag}^+ + e \longrightarrow \text{Ag}(s); \quad E^\circ = 0.80 \, \text{V} \)

Determine the potential of a Daniel cell, initially containing 1 litre solution of each 1.0 M copper (II) ion and 1.0 M zinc (II) ion after passage of \( 1 \times 10^5 \) coulomb of charge. Given \( E^\circ_{\text{Zn}/\text{Zn}^{2+}} = 0.76 \, \text{V} \) and \( E^\circ_{\text{Cu}/\text{Cu}^{2+}} = -0.34 \, \text{V} \)

In a zinc-manganese dioxide cell, the anode is made up of Zn and cathode of carbon rod surrounded by a mixture of MnO\(_2\), carbon, NH\(_4\)Cl and ZnCl\(_2\) in aqueous base. The cathodic reaction is, \( 2\text{MnO}_2(s) + \text{Zn}^{2+} + 2e \longrightarrow \text{ZnMn}_2\text{O}_4(s) \). If 8 g MnO\(_2\) is present in cathodic compartment, how many day the dry cell will continue to give a current of \( 4 \times 10^{-3} \) ampere?

\( I_2 \) and \( Br_2 \) are added to a solution containing \( I^- \) and \( Br^- \). What reaction would occur? Also calculate \( E^\circ \) for the reaction taking place. Given \( E^\circ_{I_2/I^-} = +0.54 \, \text{V} \) and \( E^\circ_{Br_2/Br^-} = +1.09 \, \text{V} \)

Given standard electrode potentials: \( I_2 + 2e \longrightarrow 2I^- \); \( E^\circ = +0.54 \, \text{V} \) \( Cl_2 + 2e \longrightarrow 2Cl^- \); \( E^\circ = +1.36 \, \text{V} \) \( Fe^{3+} + e \longrightarrow Fe^{2+} \); \( E^\circ = +0.77 \, \text{V} \) \( Ce^{4+} + e \longrightarrow Ce^{3+} \); \( E^\circ = +1.60 \, \text{V} \) \( Sn^{4+} + 2e \longrightarrow Sn^{2+} \); \( E^\circ = +0.15 \, \text{V} \)
Identify the strongest oxidant and weakest oxidant.
Identify the strongest reductant and weakest reductant.
Will \( Fe^{3+} \) oxidise \( Ce^{3+} \)?
Will \( I_2 \) replace \( Cl_2 \) from KCl?
What reaction will occur if \( SnCl_2 \) and \( FeCl_3 \) are mixed?
Will \( I_2 \) be set free on addition of \( FeCl_3 \) in KI?

\( I_2 \) and \( Br_2 \) are added to a solution containing \( I^- \) and \( Br^- \). What reaction would occur? Given \( E^\circ_{I_2/I^-} = +0.54 \, \text{V} \) and \( E^\circ_{Br_2/Br^-} = +1.09 \, \text{V} \). Also calculate \( E^\circ \) for the reaction taking place.
qOptions: \( Br_2 + I^- \longrightarrow Br^- + I_2 \) with \( E^\circ = 0.55 \, \text{V} \)
